subject: RE: [junit] Parameterized and Theories overlaps

messageBody:
I find it useful to think of a Parameterized test as a possible
*implementation* of a theory. A theory could be implemented in
some other way. And not every parameterized test represents
a theory.

IMO, whether you have a theory or not is outside the domain
of implementation and has to do with whether you are trying
to verify some sort of universal statement - not just
"my code does what this set of examples specify."

On the implementation side, I would treat the provision
of an "answer" as part of the data as a smell as far as
theory is concerned.

Charlie

> Hi,
>
> Sorry if my conclusion was indeed to "short". I feel pretty
> confident about their difference. I guess the problem i had
> and perhaps other is that whereas a theory is in fact a
> universal quantification (
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_quantification). The
> problem is, while the set for each possible value is often
> indefinite, you have to be realistic and provide appropriate
> candidate data (using data parameter supplies). And that's
> when theories start to look a lot like parameterized tests,
> while in fact they are in nature very different .
>
> Raphael
>
>
>
>
> On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 1:42 PM, Joakim Ohlrogge
> <joakim.ohlrogge@...>wrote:
>
> > > Thanks for the clear responses. What i see is that a theory is a
> > > (parametrized) test inside out; you don't specify what
> will work but
> > > you leave out what should not be tested (iow assumptions
> by leaving
> > > out the
> > data
> > > for these cases).
> >
> > I'm not sure that there is a misunderstanding here but just
> to make sure:
> >
> > While what you wrote is technically true I think it simplifies the
> > theory a bit. I would consider a long list of assumptions
> in a theory
> > a smell, perhaps named: "assmumptions is the mother of all
> screw ups"
> > :). I almost fell into the trap of using assumptions to filter the
> > "desired" datapoints to the "correct" theory but that would be a
> > violation of the idea, the idea is that the datapoints I have
> > specified and all other datapoints I (or an automatic tool)
> can come
> > up with should pass. I think that there is a subtle difference here
> > between data driven tests and theories, data driven tests
> are merely a
> > convenient way to create lots of specific examples while
> theories aim
> > at the abstraction, the definition of the truth in this system.
> >
> > If a lot of assumptions are a smell, then what are our
> weapons against
> > them? I found that declaring types help here and it pays off
> > instantly. For instance, if I represent name as a String and phone
> > number as a String and it is important to my theories to
> differentiate
> > between the two I could ether:
> >
> > Assume that any string with numbers in it is a phone number
> and that
> > anything that is not a phone number is a name.
> > Or, I could declare the type Name and the type PhoneNumber.
> >
> > In this case I would prefer a type.
> >
> > If I was intersted in defining what a long distance call is I could
> > write that as a theory:
> >
> > @Theory
> > public void makeLongDistanceCall(PhoneNumber from,
> PhoneNumber to) {
> > assumeThat(from.areaCode, is(not(equalTo(to.areaCode)));
> Call call =
> > new Call(from, to); assertTrue(call.isLongDistance());
> > }
> >
> > I probably screwed up both the domain and the design but I hope my
> > idea of what an assumptions role in a theory is and how
> theories are
> > different than data-driven tests in spite of them both
> being driven by
> > data.
> > I also hope that in the case the domain is screwed up it should be
> > perfectly clear from the above theory to anyone who knows
> the domain.
> > Finally, I hope this helps someone :)
> > /J
> >
